This is a course for master level students enrolled in the “Biologia Evoluzionistica, Ecologia e Antropologia Applicata” degree at the University of Rome Tor Vergata. Students participating to this class should have a good knowledge of zoology, ecology, population biology, genetics, and molecular biology.

title: Syllabus
text:
Learning objectives
The course aims to provide students with an overview of the problems, techniques of analysis and identification of solutions related to conservation of Biodiversity, especially at the level of population and species.
Increased knowledge on the nature of problems, development of synthetic capacities and t transversal thinking through exposure to multidisciplinary approaches.
By discussing the genetic basis of adaptation, the relationship between population size and evolutionary potential, population biology, the student develops autonomy in the process of understanding and evaluation of different approaches and methods, consolidating the awareness that conservation biology is a crisis discipline that requires specific analytical skills to guide appropriate interventions.
Development of critical skills and evaluation of diversified decision-making processes
Students develop a professional language and communication skills through a continuous confrontation with the teacher and interventions during frontal lessons. Additionally, students are guided in the understanding of the discipline also by accessing to primary literature in English. The process of development such skills is monitored by written periodical checks, with open questions.
The guided reading to the primary literature and the open discussion during class promote student’s ability to update and deepen his/her knowledge autonomously, through a better research and evaluation of sources. The transversal thinking helps students to seek and establish interdisciplinary links and develop a broad vision.

title: Syllabus
text:
Class evaluation
There will be 2 mid-term exams (see schedule page for the dates). All students have to take the midterm exams. At the end of the course, after the second mid term the student can choose to keep the grade and record it or disregard it and try for a better grade in the final written evaluation.

title: Biologia della Conservazione
text:
Changing paradigm

Biodiversity loss is a systemic problem embedded in the normal ways the human species lives on planet earth!


But now there is something new, never before seen on Earth during its billions of years of evolving species. Humans have begun to set conservation of the Biodiversity on Earth as a moral and social good. (Holmes Rolston III, 2012)


Conservation biology origins were driven by studies and discoveries in basic sciences such as genetics and population dynamics, but soon became manifest in applied sciences like forestry, fisheries, wildlife management, and more.
The extinction crisis created an urgency to develop an alternative concept to that of endangered species. That concept was biodiversity! (Dyke & Lamb, 2020)

title: Biologia della Conservazione
section: Why should we care about Biodiversity?
text:
Why should we care about Biodiversity?

A more diverse combination of species (biological community)..

… produces a more productive environment
… produces a more resistant environment
… produces a more resilient environment
… produces more stable ecosystem processes

The ESA (Ecological Society of America) concluded that maintaining biodiversity is a safeguard against risk resulting from changes in environmental conditions because it extends the productive use of a site’s resources over time and provides an effective way to provide multiple goods and services. (Hooper et al., 2005)


Biodiversity is essential for food security and nutrition and offers key options for sustainable livelihoods (Convention on Biological Diversity, https://www.cbd.int).





Multifunctional ecosystem require many species. After Duffy (2009)

title: Biologia della Conservazione
text:
What is biodiversity?



The structural and functional variety of life forms at genetic, population community and ecosystem levels (Sandlund, Hindar, & Brown, 1992).

Not simply a collection of multiple species, but an array of the biological variety.
This biological variety can be investigated at multiple levels

Genes and their variety of forms (alleles) are the most fundamental units at which biodiversity can be measured, and it is the basis for all other measures of diversity.

title: Biologia della Conservazione
text:
What is CONSERVATION BIOLOGY ?



Conservation biology is not defined by a discipline, but by its goal.





A crisis discipline, providing tools to preserve biodiversity (Soulé, 1985).




Ecologists, geneticists, zoologists, botanists, microbiologists, evolutionary biologists (etc. etc. etc.) do not stop their job and career.

title: Biologia della Conservazione
text:
Historical perspective

A relatively young field of study.

1978, First International Conference on Conservation Biology - San Diego Zoo Animal Park (CA, USA)
May 8 1985, Society for Conservation Biology (SCB), Ann Arbor (MI, USA)
June 1987, First SCB international meeting, Montana State University (MT, USA)


 

The society is a response by professionals, mostly biological and social scientists, managers and administrators to the biological diversity crisis that will reach a crescendo in the first half of the \(20^{th}\) century. We assume that we are in time, and that by joining together with each other and with other well-intentioned persons and groups, the worst biological disasters of the last 65 million years can be averted…Although we have varying philosophies, we share a faith in ourselves, as a species and as individuals, that we are equal to the challenge…For these reasons we join together in a professional alliance in the service of each other, but also in the service of the less articulate members of our evolutionary tree. (Soulé, 1987)

title: Biologia della Conservazione
text:
The origins of conservation
For thousands of years humans have managed natural resources, but did not spend much time conserving them. Yet, we have always appreciated the importance of preserving and conserving the natural environment.


Plato, through the words of Critia, laments the bad conditions of the land that is no longer productive and rich how it used to be (“Crizia,” n.d.).
Judaism extended the principle of the Sabbath to agricultural land (“La Bibbia—Leviticus 25:4—5,” n.d.).
During the Song dynasty (China, 960—1279 AD) it was common practice to set aside fengshui (sacred) portions of the land, mostly forest, to help regulating spiritual and physical power. Modern china forgo this view.



These are all historical examples that the notion (necessity!) to conserve our natural resources is well known and established in our species. Yet, we see to fail when trying to conserve our natural resources.

title: Biologia della Conservazione
text:
The “Ecologically Noble Savage” conundrum
Many have argued that our incapability to conserve is driven by greed. It may be deeper and more complicated than that!


It is hard to imagine the evolution of behavioral traits beneficial to a group of individuals if these traits are contrary to the individual’s best interest (Williams, 1966).
There is little theoretical justification for expecting individuals to conserve open access resources (Alvard, 1993).





From Alvard (1993)






From Alvard (1993)




People living in relative equilibrium with their environment are NOT necessarily conservationists.
This view comes from a definition of conservation with an emphasis on its effects rather than on the behavior.
TRUE conservation only happens when we use resources at less than maximum sustainable!
Although humans have managed natural resources for millennia they have started to conserve them only as they have embraced their intrinsic value, i.e., that they are good and valuable in and of themselves.



Scientifically valid presentation of biological problems that are relevant to the life of modern man (Ehrenfeld, 1970)



What actions can we undertake that are good for nature? This is the beginning of conservation and conservation biology in particular! (Dyke & Lamb, 2020)
